title: How to Make Paleo Stuffed Peppers

steps.headline: Saute the onion and preheat the oven.
steps.description: If you cooked bacon, ham or sausage, place 1 tablespoon of the cooking fat in a skillet. You could also use vegetable oil. Heat the fat or oil over medium-high heat and add 1 diced onion. Cook the onion until it's soft (about 4 minutes). You should also turn the oven on to 375 degrees F (190 C). Avoid overcooking the onion. It will continue to cook as you add the remaining vegetables.

steps.headline: Add the mushrooms, tomatoes, and spinach.
steps.description:
Slice 1 cup (110 g) of mushrooms and dice 1 whole tomato. Add the vegetables to the skillet with the onion and cook them for 2 minutes on medium-high heat. Stir in 3 cups (675 g) of baby spinach and continue to cook the vegetables for another minute (until it wilts). Stir in these seasonings:
Salt to taste
Pepper to taste
1/2 teaspoon of garlic powder

steps.headline: Wash and cut the bell peppers.
steps.description: Wash 4 bell peppers of any color and carefully cut them in half through the stem. Cut away and discard the stems. Remove the seeds. You may need to wash the peppers again to completely wash away the seeds. Try to choose peppers that are the same size even if they are different colors. This will ensure that they cook evenly.

steps.headline: Fill and bake the paleo-breakfast peppers.
steps.description: Scoop the vegetable filling into each of the bell pepper halves. You should beat 8 eggs in a small bowl and pour a little of the beaten eggs on top of each filled pepper half. If you want to add cooked bacon, ham or sausage, sprinkle the meat on top of the egg. Set the filled peppers on a baking sheet and bake them for 40 minutes. If you're making these to serve to guests, consider making some with meat and some without so people have a vegetarian option. If making vegetarian ones, remember to use vegetable oil instead of the cooking fat when you saute the vegetables.

steps.headline: Wash and cut the bell peppers.
steps.description: Wash 6 large bell peppers and use a sharp knife to carefully cut the tops off of the bell peppers. Remove the cores and clean out the seeds in each pepper. You may want to rinse the insides of the bell peppers to completely remove the seeds. Set the peppers aside while you make the filling. You can use red, yellow, orange, or green peppers. You can also use a combination of these, if you like.

steps.headline: Stir together the sirloin filling.
steps.description: Get out a large bowl and measure out your filling ingredients into it. You'll need to stir together 2 pounds (907 g) of ground sirloin, 1 teaspoon of garlic salt, 1 teaspoon of Italian seasoning, 1 teaspoon of basil, 1/4 teaspoon of ground black pepper, 1 egg, 1/4 cup (28 g) of coconut flour, and 1 tablespoon of the spaghetti sauce. You could substitute ground turkey for the sirloin, if you prefer.

steps.headline: Stuff the peppers with the filling and bake them in a slow cooker.
steps.description: Divide the sirloin filling between the pepper halves. You may need to use a spoon to stuff the filling down into each half. Place the stuffed peppers in a slow cooker and pour 1/4 cup (55 g) of the spaghetti sauce over each of them. Put the lid on the cooker and bake the peppers for 4 to 5 hours on HIGH or 6 to 8 hours on LOW. If you don't want to cook the peppers in a slow cooker, you can bake them in the oven. Cook them in an oven preheated to 375 degrees F (190 C) for about 40 minutes.

steps.headline: Saute the onion, garlic and chili.
steps.description: Pour 2 tablespoons of extra virgin olive oil into a large skillet. Turn the heat on to medium and once the oil shimmers, stir in ½ cup (75 g) of chopped onion, 4 cloves of minced garlic, and 1 seeded and chopped medium jalapeño or serrano chile. Cook the aromatics for about 2 minutes. Stir the onion, garlic, and chili frequently since they will stick to the pan easily.

steps.headline: Add the ground chicken and seasoning.
steps.description: Stir in 2 pounds (907 g) of ground chicken or turkey and cook the meat until it's not pink in the center. The temperature should reach 165 degrees F (73 C). Sprinkle 2 tablespoons of Mexican seasoning over the meat and onion mixture. Stir the filling mixture so the seasoning is incorporated.

steps.headline: Add diced tomatoes and cook the Mexican chili filling.
steps.description: Open 1 14.5-ounce can of no-salt-added fire-roasted diced tomatoes and stir it into the skillet. Don't drain the tomatoes before you add them. Bring the mixture to a boil and turn the heat down. Let the filling bubble lightly for 5 to 7 minutes. Stir in 1/4 cup of chopped cilantro. Keep the filling mixture uncovered while it cooks. This will help most of the liquid evaporate and will concentrate the flavor.

steps.headline: Cut and boil the bell peppers.
steps.description: Wash 4 medium red, yellow or orange sweet bell peppers. Use a sharp knife to carefully cut away the stems. Remove the seeds. You may need to rinse them to completely get them out of the peppers. Bring a large pot of water to a boil and add the bell peppers. Boil them for 2 to 3 minutes. Carefully lift them out of the water using a slotted spoon. The peppers should be a little tender. Boiling the peppers means that you won't need to bake the stuffed peppers.

steps.headline: Fill and serve the Mexican chicken peppers.
steps.description:
Use a spoon to fill each of the cooked peppers with the Mexican chicken mixture. To serve them, place two filled peppers on a plate and garnish them with:
Chopped cilantro
Lime wedges
Cauliflower rice

text:
Making Paleo-Breakfast Stuffed Peppers Saute the onion and preheat the oven. If you cooked bacon, ham or sausage, place 1 tablespoon of the cooking fat in a skillet. You could also use vegetable oil. Heat the fat or oil over medium-high heat and add 1 diced onion. Cook the onion until it's soft (about 4 minutes). You should also turn the oven on to 375 degrees F (190 C). Avoid overcooking the onion. It will continue to cook as you add the remaining vegetables. Add the mushrooms, tomatoes, and spinach. Slice 1 cup (110 g) of mushrooms and dice 1 whole tomato. Add the vegetables to the skillet with the onion and cook them for 2 minutes on medium-high heat. Stir in 3 cups (675 g) of baby spinach and continue to cook the vegetables for another minute (until it wilts). Stir in these seasonings:
Salt to taste
Pepper to taste
1/2 teaspoon of garlic powder Wash and cut the bell peppers. Wash 4 bell peppers of any color and carefully cut them in half through the stem. Cut away and discard the stems. Remove the seeds. You may need to wash the peppers again to completely wash away the seeds. Try to choose peppers that are the same size even if they are different colors. This will ensure that they cook evenly. Fill and bake the paleo-breakfast peppers. Scoop the vegetable filling into each of the bell pepper halves. You should beat 8 eggs in a small bowl and pour a little of the beaten eggs on top of each filled pepper half. If you want to add cooked bacon, ham or sausage, sprinkle the meat on top of the egg. Set the filled peppers on a baking sheet and bake them for 40 minutes. If you're making these to serve to guests, consider making some with meat and some without so people have a vegetarian option. If making vegetarian ones, remember to use vegetable oil instead of the cooking fat when you saute the vegetables. Making Sirloin-Stuffed Paleo Peppers Wash and cut the bell peppers. Wash 6 large bell peppers and use a sharp knife to carefully cut the tops off of the bell peppers. Remove the cores and clean out the seeds in each pepper. You may want to rinse the insides of the bell peppers to completely remove the seeds. Set the peppers aside while you make the filling. You can use red, yellow, orange, or green peppers. You can also use a combination of these, if you like. Stir together the sirloin filling. Get out a large bowl and measure out your filling ingredients into it. You'll need to stir together 2 pounds (907 g) of ground sirloin, 1 teaspoon of garlic salt, 1 teaspoon of Italian seasoning, 1 teaspoon of basil, 1/4 teaspoon of ground black pepper, 1 egg, 1/4 cup (28 g) of coconut flour, and 1 tablespoon of the spaghetti sauce. You could substitute ground turkey for the sirloin, if you prefer. Stuff the peppers with the filling and bake them in a slow cooker. Divide the sirloin filling between the pepper halves. You may need to use a spoon to stuff the filling down into each half. Place the stuffed peppers in a slow cooker and pour 1/4 cup (55 g) of the spaghetti sauce over each of them. Put the lid on the cooker and bake the peppers for 4 to 5 hours on HIGH or 6 to 8 hours on LOW. If you don't want to cook the peppers in a slow cooker, you can bake them in the oven. Cook them in an oven preheated to 375 degrees F (190 C) for about 40 minutes. Making Mexican Chicken Stuffed Peppers Saute the onion, garlic and chili. Pour 2 tablespoons of extra virgin olive oil into a large skillet. Turn the heat on to medium and once the oil shimmers, stir in ½ cup (75 g) of chopped onion, 4 cloves of minced garlic, and 1 seeded and chopped medium jalapeño or serrano chile. Cook the aromatics for about 2 minutes. Stir the onion, garlic, and chili frequently since they will stick to the pan easily. Add the ground chicken and seasoning. Stir in 2 pounds (907 g) of ground chicken or turkey and cook the meat until it's not pink in the center. The temperature should reach 165 degrees F (73 C). Sprinkle 2 tablespoons of Mexican seasoning over the meat and onion mixture. Stir the filling mixture so the seasoning is incorporated. Add diced tomatoes and cook the Mexican chili filling. Open 1 14.5-ounce can of no-salt-added fire-roasted diced tomatoes and stir it into the skillet. Don't drain the tomatoes before you add them. Bring the mixture to a boil and turn the heat down. Let the filling bubble lightly for 5 to 7 minutes. Stir in 1/4 cup of chopped cilantro. Keep the filling mixture uncovered while it cooks. This will help most of the liquid evaporate and will concentrate the flavor. Cut and boil the bell peppers. Wash 4 medium red, yellow or orange sweet bell peppers. Use a sharp knife to carefully cut away the stems. Remove the seeds. You may need to rinse them to completely get them out of the peppers. Bring a large pot of water to a boil and add the bell peppers. Boil them for 2 to 3 minutes. Carefully lift them out of the water using a slotted spoon. The peppers should be a little tender. Boiling the peppers means that you won't need to bake the stuffed peppers. Fill and serve the Mexican chicken peppers. Use a spoon to fill each of the cooked peppers with the Mexican chicken mixture. To serve them, place two filled peppers on a plate and garnish them with:
Chopped cilantro
Lime wedges
Cauliflower rice
sentences: Making Paleo-Breakfast Stuffed Peppers Saute the onion and preheat the oven.
If you cooked bacon, ham or sausage, place 1 tablespoon of the cooking fat in a skillet.
You could also use vegetable oil.
Heat the fat or oil over medium-high heat and add 1 diced onion.
Cook the onion until it's soft (about 4 minutes).
You should also turn the oven on to 375 degrees F (190 C).
Avoid overcooking the onion.
It will continue to cook as you add the remaining vegetables.
Add the mushrooms, tomatoes, and spinach.
Slice 1 cup (110 g) of mushrooms and dice 1 whole tomato.
Add the vegetables to the skillet with the onion and cook them for 2 minutes on medium-high heat.
Stir in 3 cups (675 g) of baby spinach and continue to cook the vegetables for another minute (until it wilts).

Stir in these seasonings:
Salt to taste
Pepper to taste
1/2 teaspoon of garlic powder Wash and cut the bell peppers.
Wash 4 bell peppers of any color and carefully cut them in half through the stem.
Cut away and discard the stems.
Remove the seeds.
You may need to wash the peppers again to completely wash away the seeds.
Try to choose peppers that are the same size even if they are different colors.
This will ensure that they cook evenly.
Fill and bake the paleo-breakfast peppers.
Scoop the vegetable filling into each of the bell pepper halves.
You should beat 8 eggs in a small bowl and pour a little of the beaten eggs on top of each filled pepper half.
If you want to add cooked bacon, ham or sausage, sprinkle the meat on top of the egg.
Set the filled peppers on a baking sheet and bake them for 40 minutes.
If you're making these to serve to guests, consider making some with meat and some without so people have a vegetarian option.
If making vegetarian ones, remember to use vegetable oil instead of the cooking fat when you saute the vegetables.
Making Sirloin-Stuffed Paleo Peppers Wash and cut the bell peppers.
Wash 6 large bell peppers and use a sharp knife to carefully cut the tops off of the bell peppers.
Remove the cores and clean out the seeds in each pepper.
You may want to rinse the insides of the bell peppers to completely remove the seeds.
Set the peppers aside while you make the filling.
You can use red, yellow, orange, or green peppers.
You can also use a combination of these, if you like.
Stir together the sirloin filling.
Get out a large bowl and measure out your filling ingredients into it.

You'll need to stir together 2 pounds (907 g) of ground sirloin, 1 teaspoon of garlic salt, 1 teaspoon of Italian seasoning, 1 teaspoon of basil, 1/4 teaspoon of ground black pepper, 1 egg, 1/4 cup (28 g) of coconut flour, and 1 tablespoon of the spaghetti sauce.
You could substitute ground turkey for the sirloin, if you prefer.
Stuff the peppers with the filling and bake them in a slow cooker.
Divide the sirloin filling between the pepper halves.
You may need to use a spoon to stuff the filling down into each half.
Place the stuffed peppers in a slow cooker and pour 1/4 cup (55 g) of the spaghetti sauce over each of them.
Put the lid on the cooker and bake the peppers for 4 to 5 hours on HIGH or 6 to 8 hours on LOW.
If you don't want to cook the peppers in a slow cooker, you can bake them in the oven.
Cook them in an oven preheated to 375 degrees F (190 C) for about 40 minutes.
Making Mexican Chicken Stuffed Peppers Saute the onion, garlic and chili.
Pour 2 tablespoons of extra virgin olive oil into a large skillet.
Turn the heat on to medium and once the oil shimmers, stir in ½ cup (75 g) of chopped onion, 4 cloves of minced garlic, and 1 seeded and chopped medium jalapeño or serrano chile.
Cook the aromatics for about 2 minutes.
Stir the onion, garlic, and chili frequently since they will stick to the pan easily.
Add the ground chicken and seasoning.
Stir in 2 pounds (907 g) of ground chicken or turkey and cook the meat until it's not pink in the center.
The temperature should reach 165 degrees F (73 C).
Sprinkle 2 tablespoons of Mexican seasoning over the meat and onion mixture.
Stir the filling mixture so the seasoning is incorporated.
Add diced tomatoes and cook the Mexican chili filling.
Open 1 14.5-ounce can of no-salt-added fire-roasted diced tomatoes and stir it into the skillet.
Don't drain the tomatoes before you add them.
Bring the mixture to a boil and turn the heat down.
Let the filling bubble lightly for 5 to 7 minutes.
Stir in 1/4 cup of chopped cilantro.
Keep the filling mixture uncovered while it cooks.
This will help most of the liquid evaporate and will concentrate the flavor.
Cut and boil the bell peppers.
Wash 4 medium red, yellow or orange sweet bell peppers.
Use a sharp knife to carefully cut away the stems.
Remove the seeds.
You may need to rinse them to completely get them out of the peppers.
Bring a large pot of water to a boil and add the bell peppers.
Boil them for 2 to 3 minutes.
Carefully lift them out of the water using a slotted spoon.
The peppers should be a little tender.
Boiling the peppers means that you won't need to bake the stuffed peppers.
Fill and serve the Mexican chicken peppers.
Use a spoon to fill each of the cooked peppers with the Mexican chicken mixture.

To serve them, place two filled peppers on a plate and garnish them with:
Chopped cilantro
Lime wedges
Cauliflower rice
